SUMMARY: PhoP is a dual transcriptional regulator that is activated in response to low extracellular levels of divalent cations, e.g., magnesium or calcium [1530848, 1729240, 10464230]. In Escherichia coli K-12, PhoP activates transcription of a large collection of genes involved in Mg2+ homeostasis, resistance to antimicrobial peptides, acid resistance, and LPS modification [10464230, 12813061, 17909183]. PhoP belongs to OmpR/PhoB subfamily of response regulators characterized by a winged-helix DNA-binding domain. structure of N-terminal receiver domain has been solved in absence and presence of phosphoryl analog beryllofluoride [17545283]. PhoP is phosphorylated and reby activated by its cognate sensor kinase PhoQ at a low extracellular concentration of magnesium. At high levels of magnesium phospho-PhoP phosphatase activity of sensor protein is induced [10807931]. Regulation of PhoQ/PhoP system is connected to EvgS/EvgA system through small inner membrane protein B1500. EvgS/EvgA system is involved in acid resistance and directly regulates expression of B1500. B1500 interacts with PhoQ and increases level of PhoP phosphorylation [17998538]. PhoP-P binds to tandemly arranged binding sites known as PhoP boxes, consisting of two direct repeats separated by 5 nucleotides [10464230]. C-terminal domain of σ subunit (σ CTD) is required for recruitment of RNA polymerase [12123454].
